fields.description:
*UPDATE: As of UPM 2.14.2+, this bug prevents users from installing plugins through UPM in addition to the previous "anonymous" audit log behavior. See the comments below for more information.*

When upgrading UPM 2.0 tests to run against Bamboo 3.4 (instead of Bamboo 3.4-rc2), I noticed a test fail.  I tracked it down to Bamboo's SAL implementation of {{UserManager.getRemoteUsername()}} returning {{null}} when running in a transaction ({{TxTemplate}}) inside a {{Callable}} executed by an executor created by {{ThreadLocalDelegateExecutorFactory}}.  I spent some time trying to generate a minimal reproducer, but the simple case was working fine for me.

What I can tell you is that this functionality was working OK with Bamboo 3.4-rc2 but broke in the Bamboo 3.4 release.  To reproduce, you can check out r132786 of [UPM|https://studio.atlassian.com/svn/UPM/trunk]. If you want to run Bamboo+UPM 2.0 from the UPM tree, build everything with {{mvn clean install -DskipTests}}, then run {{mvn amps:debug -Pbamboo34 -Dproduct=bamboo}} from the {{integration-tests}} directory.  

*If you install a plugin via UPM UI and then check the Audit Log, you'll see that the log entry is attributed to "anonymous" but should be "admin" (or whoever the current user is).*

This issue corresponds to [UPM-1521|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-1521].
fields.summary: UserManager.getRemoteUsername() returns null (in some context) despite being authenticated

fields.description:
We have many Bamboo agents and projects on multiple OS configurations. Specifically when the agent is running on an OSX machine:

Bamboo intermittently reports failures prior to building a stage, not necessarily the first stage, with the error message "﻿Error occurred while executing the build for PROJECTAND-AGENTINFO-BUILDSTEPNAME-## : Unable to extract client root from Perforce, therefore could not evaluate where the source will be checked out to."

When running the agent in console mode, no errors are reported when this happens. This happens intermittently but often, on every project built by the OSX agent. Perforce ticket expiration for the build account is a few days.

The problem used to occur prior to a build's first stage after long periods of inactivity (say, coming back to work Monday morning). Now, however, it's happening to seemingly random steps at anytime. Sometimes retrying failed jobs succeeds, only to have the next stage fail. This intermittency, paired with a complete lack of ANY Perforce problems on the system outside of those Bamboo is reporting, leads me to believe that the reported error is inaccurate.

I would like to ask (a) for help debugging this problem, and (b) that this error message never appear unless there actually is a problem with Perforce client retrieval, and that any other error report a more appropriate message.
fields.summary: Bamboo builds erroneously fail, seemingly at random, with bogus Perforce error on OSX agents

fields.description:
The problem happens if a user logged in to Bamboo keeps the web console open in the browser and without use for approximately one hour. After this time frame, if the user try to use any of the console options, the page is refreshed and the Login page is displayed on the top of the page that the user was trying to use.

The problem happens only if Bamboo is installed in a Tomcat application server.

Please, see the *workaround* described in [this KB Article|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/User+Session+Timeout+Happening+After+One+Hour]

fields.description:
see [here|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo/src/344259e3e561/components/bamboo-plugins/bamboo-plugin-mercurial/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/plugins/hg/HgRepository.java#cl-149]. HgRepository.getHost() returns null, where it should somehow discover the remote repository IP.

Problem:
1) setup a bamboo plan using Mercurial repository
2) setup plan to trigger builds by repository, setup a hook in your .hg (see [BSP-6009|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-6009] if you are lost)
3) push some changes to the repository
4a) expected behaviour is that the plan is triggered and running
4b) while nothing happens
5) edit plan details -> trigger strategy -> add "trigger Ip address" equal to IP of your repository, push some changes to the repository
6) build will run as expected

It would be nice to get rid of the step 5 of possible.
fields.summary: Mercurial repository should be able to discover repository IP address (for repository triggering)

fields.description:
For some of our plans, we build off long-standing branches.
We specify the branch path in our plan repository configuration.
One of our devs noticed just today that the plan was reporting having used the latest revision of the repo instead of the latest revision of the branch.

I think it would be more intuitive if Bamboo did one of two things when checking out a branch/tag:
1. Show the latest branch/tag revision
2. Show the repo latest revision AND the branch/tag revision
fields.summary: Bamboo shows latest global SVN repo revision, even when checking out from older branch/tag

fields.description:
I've noticed that although I have the global concurrency set to 2, this is not checked after the initial launch of jobs.  If one job in a multi-job stage finishes before another, Bamboo will not launch the third job in the stage until the second job has completed.

The setup I have is a stage with 3 jobs, A, B and C which are not dependent on each other.  When running the plan, Bamboo launches jobs A and B at the same time.  The expected behaviour is that job C will be launched as soon as job A or job B has finished.  The observed behaviour is that both jobs A and B must have finished before job C will be started.
fields.summary: Multiple jobs in a stage do not observe concurrency setting

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

1) Create a plan and add a P4 Repository to it.
2) Add a new P4 Repo to the Plan
3) Add the second repo to the Source Code Checkout Task that already exists.
4) Check tab "Job Details". The select box is displayed and changeable, select option "Repository as Working Directory"
5) Remove the old/first Repository from the "Source Code Checkout" Task
6) Check "Job Details". The select-box isn't displayed anymore
7) Go to Plan "Source Repositories" and delete the old/first Repository.
8) Go to Job - Check Job Details - you will not see a Working Directory select-box
9) Go to "Source Code Checkout" Task and add another Repository (you should only have the possibility to select the new/second created Repository (because the first has been deleted)
10) Go back to Job Details, you will see the select-box for the "Working Directory", but the configured value now is "Default Working Directory"

Running the build after having done these steps, will checkout the code the normal P4 Workspace, however the other tasks will be run in the traditional xml-data build-dir path.
fields.summary: Specific steps make Tasks be run outside the Perforce Workspace

fields.description:
Removing a repository on the plan level, 
a) does not delete usages of it from the JOB.  
b) it also doesn't warn you that your build will be screwed.  
c) is actually allowed even if it is being used. 

I immediately pressed play after removing the repo and the build failed with "can not find repository with id 568445".

I then go to edit the source directory task and I see two checkout items with the SAME repository picked in the drop down (becuase presumably the UI couldn't figure out which one to pick so picked the first.)

I am not allowed to remove the first repository checkout - even though that is the one that is technically broken

Build Working Directory is reverted to "Default Working Directory", even though this is never used as the dedault anywhere else (The first checkout repository was always selected as the default when I didn't pick anything)
fields.summary: Confusion/Errors when deleting repository that is used by checkout task

fields.description:
I'm hoping this will prove to be a case of my not seeing an existing feature.


How do I get an RSS feed of artifacts available from a particular build?  Ideally this is linked from the RSS output for each plan, perhaps <artifacts>some.rss.url</artifacts> .


Within Bamboo, I've set up a number of plans which test our monitoring/routing/server/etc configuration files for correctness and do some other massaging, and then save the ready-to-be-deployed configuration files as Bamboo artifacts.  External to Bamboo,I have a number of scripts which regularly check the per-plan RSS feed for a new successful build, figure out the URL to download artifacts, download the artifacts/updated configuration files, and finally restart whatever process consumes those files.


This works well, until the next Bamboo upgrade introduces subtle changes to the artifact page, and this page scraping breaks until fixed.
fields.summary: Bamboo Artifact RSS feed

I think that script tasks should log more verbose information what exactly they are calling. Currently we log only:
{noformat}
command	11-Nov-2011 17:22:56	Beginning to execute external process for build 'Balamut - Development - Build Binaries'
 ... running command line: 
C:\Windows\Temp\BM-DEV-BUILD-19-ScriptBuildTask-8702631589384767807.bat
 ... in: D:\Bamboo\xml-data\build-dir\131073\SPRD-DEV-BUILD
 ... using extra environment variables: 
HOME=D:\Bamboo
bamboo_Platform=x64
bamboo_Configuration=Release
{noformat}
while it would be more valuable (from support/DoS perspective) to have something like:
{noformat}
command	11-Nov-2011 17:22:56	Beginning to execute external process for build 'Spreader - Development - Build Binaries'
 ... running command line: 
make clean
make -f Makefile.x86
scp Release/Balamut.exe http://www.balamut.com/releases

HOME=D:\Bamboo
bamboo_Platform=x64
bamboo_Configuration=Release
{noformat}

Can we implement that somewhere in future? I'm getting struck with that from time to time when doing DoS...

fields.description:
We have 2 Bamboo plugins written in Scala, one that contains tasks and is supposed to run on remote agents, the other is a plugin supposed to run on the server.

To avoid bundling the scala library with the plugins, it's depending on a [Scala provider plugin|https://plugins.atlassian.com/plugin/details/372272] (OSGIfied jar with an {{atlassian-plugin.xml}}) that only exports {{scala.*}} packages but doesn't contain any plugin modules.

Unfortunately the agent plugin fails to start as apparently the scala provider plugin doesn't get downloaded to the remote agent.

{code}
atlassian-bamboo.log:75482:2011-12-06 21:54:57,056 ERROR [Thread-1] [OsgiPlugin] Detected an error (BundleException) enabling the plugin 'com.atlassian.idd.bamboo-agent-tasks' : Unresolved constraint in bundle com.atlassian.idd.bamboo-agent-tasks [12]: Unable to resolve 12.0: missing requirement [12.0] package; (&(package=scala)(version>=2.9.0.1)).  This error usually occurs when your plugin imports a package from another bundle with a specific version constraint and either the bundle providing that package doesn't meet those version constraints, or there is no bundle available that provides the specified package. For more details on how to fix this, see http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/1xy6D
atlassian-bamboo.log:75524:Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Unresolved constraint in bundle com.atlassian.idd.bamboo-agent-tasks [12]: Unable to resolve 12.0: missing requirement [12.0] package; (&(package=scala)(version>=2.9.0.1))
atlassian-bamboo.log:75572:Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Unresolved constraint in bundle com.atlassian.idd.bamboo-agent-tasks [12]: Unable to resolve 12.0: missing requirement [12.0] package; (&(package=scala)(version>=2.9.0.1))
{code}

Workaround is to simply bundle that dependency (which you would have to do with a plugins 1 plugin anyway).
fields.summary: Agent tasks fail to execute on remote agents if they depend on packages exported by library bundles

fields.description:
Bamboo should check if /dev/tty exists before assigning that to BAMBOO_CONSOLE and using in bamboo.sh.

We should write to /dev/null if tty is not available.

Maybe something like:
{code}
if [ -w /dev/tty ]
then
BAMBOO_CONSOLE=/dev/tty
else
#perhaps write to /dev/null?
fi
{code}

fields.description:
We need to configure Bamboo to connect to IM servers through a proxy (using SOCKS or HTTP CONNECT) for Atlassian OnDemand.

Smack supports this through the {{ConnectionConfiguration}} class (http://fisheye.igniterealtime.org/changelog/smack?cs=10673).

This is required to solve https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5448

This configuration should be restricted to system administrators, and should not be permitted by restricted admins. It is invariant on the Unicorn platform, so from our perspective it would be fine to configure it through a system property or configuration file, rather than in the database.

fields.description:
I assume that the Source Repository Aliases are add when Bamboo checks out source code and doesn't find it in the existing aliases. However, you give the opportunity to add new aliases in the User Profile, but don't allow to remove the existing ones. I get that allowing a removal of all aliases would be also wrong since a user does not necessarily own them. Thus I'd suggest restricting the functionality of adding/removing aliases to admins and remove it completely from the User Profile.

Also adding an alias causes a deselection of the already selected aliases.
fields.summary: User Profile: It's not possible to remove a Source Repository Aliases created by me and adding it causes a deselection of the selected ones

fields.description:
My ~/.gitconfig contains the following

{noformat}
[user]

        name = Fabian Kraemer
{noformat}

which then leads to the alias "Fabian Kraemer <fakraemer@atlassian.com>" being created. This alias gets shown HTML encoded on the /profile/userProfile.action but is correctly displayed in the select box of /profile/editProfile.action.

fields.summary: It shouldn't be possible to create capability that you can't edit/delete due to special characters used in the key

fields.description:
e.g.

http://localhost:3990/upm/plugins/servlet/upm#manage/com.atlassian.upm.license-checker-test-plugin

gets changed to 

http://localhost:3990/upm/plugins/servlet/manage/com.atlassian.upm.license-checker-test-plugin

This currently prevents direct linking to plugin configuration on the UPM page.
fields.summary: History.JS munges hashtags in urls

fields.description:
Through parent and child chaining, it is possible for the successful building of one project to start the building of another project.  For a main project that has dependencies which must be built and up to date, however, it is intuitive to click "build" on the main project, and expect its dependencies to be checked and if need be built.  As it stands, one must create the build chain and then execute a build on the first project in the chain.

The option to set dependencies that must be built *before* the current project would make more an overall more intuitive dependency chain.
fields.summary: Option to reverse order of builds for dependency chaining.

fields.description: Script Task is hardcoded to use {{/bin/sh}}. Would be convenient for the user to provide an alternative shell.
fields.summary: Use alternative shell other than /bin/sh for Script Task

fields.description:
If seems that the quick commit links on the bamboo summary has been lost for git repos. Compare eg:
https://jira.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/JIRAHEAD-UNIT-7186 (an svn repo)
to
https://jira.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/JIRAGITTEST-UNITGIT-5
Looks like link is there on the commits tab has been dropped in development.

If it's cool and you can point me to where the source is, I'm happy to fix this.

fields.description:
The *Stage* is marked for deletion at table CHAIN_STAGE. Constraint FKF88809E0D324424A refers to the relationship between table ARTIFACT_DEFINITION and BUILD.

All the Jobs referring the Stage were already removed from the BUILD table and Artifacts from ARTIFACT_DEFINITION, however Bamboo is not able to remove the marked entry from CHAIN_STAGE.

*Workaround:* Remove manually from CHAIN_STAGE table the entries marked for deletion. This operation will be successful only if all the other tables already had their entries deleted. So, this operation will not create orphans in the DB. 
{code}
DELETE FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE MARKED_FOR_DELETION = true;
{code}

fields.description:
details here: [BSP-5897|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-5897]

Marcin, 

I believe there is some bug in the cleaning up repositoryData.xml logic - I can't nail it down, but it seems to me that in [some circumstances|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo/annotate/22e3d200eae2/components/bamboo-core/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/v2/build/task/InitializeBuild.java#line-204] it will ask plan repositories for their SourceCodeDirectory, even if the current Job doesn't need to use the repositoryData at all (because there is no VcsCheckoutTask).

Usually it's not a problem, but if you set up multi-job-multi-stage plan you may end in the situation where for example perforce-less agent is [asked for his perforce root|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo/annotate/22e3d200eae2/components/bamboo-core/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/repository/perforce/PerforceRepository.java#line-610]! Of course in such situation we error out the build, which is not supposed to happening.

May I request your comment? :)

fields.description:
1. install Jira 4.4.3 or 5.0-beta3
2. install Bamboo 3.3.3
3. Create an Applink between them. This could be either trusted app or OAuth
4. Create a project in Jira. Create a build project in Bamboo.
5. Link the project o the build project.
6. From Jira, go to the build tab of the project
7. This message will appear "Unable to connect to Bamboo server. Please check your configuration and ensure that the Bamboo server is running."

At first I thought this might be AppLink problem but it turns out it seems more like a Bamboo bug. The error log on Bamboo side reads:-

fields.summary: Builds tab in JIRA throws errors when no builds

fields.description:
We need to make sure that the Bamboo Server will be able to identify the exact agent remote address for the [Agent Authentication feature|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-2111].

Currently, the Sever obtains the Agent IP using HTTP "remote-address" header. If one or more proxies are between the Server and the Agent, the proxy IP will come in the *remote-address* header and the real Agent IP will come in the *X-Forwarder-For* header. If there are multiple proxies between the Server and the Agent, there will be multiple IPs defined at X-Forwarder-For.

In the way that it is implemented now, the Server will be approving the proxy IP, not the Agent IP.
fields.summary: Support Agent Authentication when Proxy Servers are between the Bamboo Server and the Agent

fields.description:
If you hit two project tab panels at the same time you will get the same results on both pages.  I'm assuming its in the plugin not the server, because it happens even when its supposed to be hitting two different servers.  


Affects 5.0-m* versions of the plugin, have not tested on 4.3 (I presume it will have the same problem).
It may also be a problem on issue and version tab panels, have not yet tested.
fields.summary: JBAM - Concurrency Bug when hitting project tab panel
